name: Hydrogen
naturalOccurrence: Abundant in universe, especially in stars
hazards: Highly flammable
spectralLines: Lyman series
Balmer series
funFacts: Hydrogen is the most abundant chemical substance in the universe.

name: Helium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in natural gas deposits
hazards: Asphyxiation in confined spaces
spectralLines: Helium I
Helium II
funFacts: Helium is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe.

name: Lithium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like spodumene and lepidolite
hazards: Highly reactive, especially in water
spectralLines: D-lines at 670.8 nm and 610.4 nm
funFacts: Lithium is the lightest metal and the least dense solid element.

name: Beryllium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like beryl and chrysoberyl
hazards: Toxic if inhaled as dust or fumes
spectralLines: Be I lines in the ultraviolet spectrum
funFacts: Beryllium is used as a hardening agent in alloys.

name: Boron
naturalOccurrence: Found in borate minerals
hazards: May cause skin and eye irritation
spectralLines: Boron I lines in the ultraviolet spectrum
funFacts: Boron is essential for plant growth.

name: Carbon
naturalOccurrence: Found in all organic life forms and in minerals like graphite and diamond
hazards: Inhalation of fine carbon dust may cause respiratory issues
spectralLines: Lines in ultraviolet and visible spectra
funFacts: Carbon forms more compounds than any other element.

name: Nitrogen
naturalOccurrence: Makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Asphyxiation in confined spaces
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectra
funFacts: Nitrogen is essential for amino acids and proteins in living organisms.

name: Oxygen
naturalOccurrence: Second most abundant element in Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Supports combustion, causing fires to burn more vigorously
spectralLines: Lines in the UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Oxygen is essential for aerobic life forms.

name: Fluorine
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like fluorite
hazards: Extremely reactive and corrosive
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Fluorine is the most electronegative element.

name: Neon
naturalOccurrence: Found in small amounts in Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Non-toxic but displaces oxygen in confined spaces
spectralLines: Bright red-orange emission lines
funFacts: Neon produces a distinct reddish-orange glow in discharge tubes.

name: Sodium
naturalOccurrence: Common in salts like halite
hazards: Highly reactive with water
spectralLines: D-lines at 589.0 and 589.6 nm
funFacts: Sodium reacts explosively with water to form hydrogen gas.

name: Magnesium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like dolomite and magnesite
hazards: Can ignite and burn with a bright flame
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Magnesium is essential for biological functions such as enzyme reactions.

name: Aluminum
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like bauxite
hazards: Can react with acids and alkalis
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Aluminum is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.

name: Silicon
color: Dark gray with a metallic luster
naturalOccurrence: Occurs abundantly in sand, rocks, and minerals
hazards: Can cause respiratory issues if inhaled as dust
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Silicon is essential for electronics and computing industries.

name: Phosphorus
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like apatite
hazards: Highly reactive and flammable in certain forms
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Phosphorus is essential for life, playing a key role in DNA and energy transfer.

name: Sulfur
naturalOccurrence: Found in volcanic areas and minerals like gypsum
hazards: Can form toxic gases when burned
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Sulfur has a distinctive smell and is vital for proteins and enzymes.

name: Chlorine
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in salt deposits and sea water
hazards: Highly toxic and corrosive
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Chlorine was used in chemical warfare during World War I.

name: Argon
naturalOccurrence: Makes up about 0.93% of Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Non-toxic but can displace oxygen in confined spaces
spectralLines: Bright emission lines in red and green
funFacts: Argon is used in fluorescent and LED lighting.

name: Potassium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like sylvite and in sea water
hazards: Highly reactive, especially with water
spectralLines: Lines in red spectrum
funFacts: Potassium ions are vital for nerve and muscle function.

name: Calcium
naturalOccurrence: Abundant in Earth's crust and bones
hazards: Reacts with acids and water, producing hydrogen gas
spectralLines: Lines in visible spectrum
funFacts: Calcium is essential for bone structure and muscle contraction.

name: Scandium
naturalOccurrence: Found in rare minerals such as thortveitite
hazards: Low toxicity but should be handled with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Scandium is a rare and expensive metal with specialized applications.

name: Titanium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like ilmenite and rutile
hazards: Generally considered safe, but dust may be hazardous
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Titanium is known for its strength, lightness, and corrosion resistance.

name: Vanadium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like vanadinite
hazards: Toxic in large amounts, can cause irritation
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Vanadium alloys are used in high-strength steel products.

name: Chromium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in chromite ore
hazards: Some chromium compounds are toxic and carcinogenic
spectralLines: Lines in visible and UV spectrum
funFacts: Chromium gives stainless steel its corrosion resistance.

name: Manganese
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like pyrolusite
hazards: Excessive exposure can cause neurological damage
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Manganese is essential for bone formation and metabolism.

name: Iron
naturalOccurrence: Found in Earth's core and ores like hematite
hazards: Excessive iron can cause poisoning
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Iron is the most used metal worldwide.

name: Cobalt
naturalOccurrence: Found in ores like cobaltite
hazards: Excessive exposure may affect the heart and lungs
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Cobalt is used in rechargeable battery technology.

name: Nickel
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like pentlandite
hazards: Can cause skin allergies and respiratory issues
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Nickel is highly resistant to corrosion and oxidation.

name: Copper
naturalOccurrence: Found in ores like chalcopyrite
hazards: Excessive exposure may cause gastrointestinal issues
spectralLines: Lines in green and red spectrum
funFacts: Copper has the highest electrical conductivity of non-precious metals.

name: Zinc
naturalOccurrence: Found in ores like sphalerite
hazards: Excessive intake may cause nausea and other health issues
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible spectrum
funFacts: Zinc is essential for immune system function.

name: Gallium
naturalOccurrence: Found in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores
hazards: Low toxicity but should be handled with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Gallium melts just above room temperature and can melt in your hand.

name: Germanium
naturalOccurrence: Found in small amounts in minerals like argyrodite
hazards: Generally low toxicity but dust can be hazardous
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Germanium is important for high-speed electronics and infrared optics.

name: Arsenic
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like arsenopyrite
hazards: Highly toxic and carcinogenic
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Arsenic has been historically used as a poison and medicinal compound.

name: Selenium
naturalOccurrence: Found in sulfide ores and in small amounts in soil
hazards: Toxic in high doses
spectralLines: Lines in visible spectrum
funFacts: Selenium is essential for antioxidant enzymes in the body.

name: Bromine
naturalOccurrence: Found in sea water and mineral deposits
hazards: Corrosive and toxic to skin and eyes
spectralLines: Lines in red spectrum
funFacts: Bromine is one of only two elements that is liquid at room temperature.

name: Krypton
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in trace amounts in Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Inert gas; generally non-toxic but can displace oxygen in confined spaces
spectralLines: Lines in the red, green, and blue regions of the spectrum
funFacts: Krypton is used in certain types of photographic flashes and high-performance light bulbs.

name: Rubidium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in trace amounts in minerals like lepidolite and pollucite
hazards: Highly reactive; can cause fires and explosions when in contact with water
spectralLines: Lines in the red and violet regions of the spectrum
funFacts: Rubidium is used in research related to quantum computing and atomic clocks.

name: Strontium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like celestine and strontianite
hazards: Compounds can be toxic if ingested; strontium-90 is radioactive
spectralLines: Lines in the red and orange regions of the spectrum
funFacts: Strontium compounds are responsible for the red color in fireworks.

name: Yttrium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in rare earth minerals like xenotime and monazite
hazards: Generally low toxicity; compounds can be harmful if inhaled or ingested
spectralLines: Lines in the red and green regions of the spectrum
funFacts: Yttrium is used in the production of phosphors for color television tubes.

name: Zirconium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like zircon and baddeleyite
hazards: Generally low toxicity; compounds can be harmful if inhaled or ingested
spectralLines: Lines in the ultraviolet region of the spectrum
funFacts: Zirconium is highly resistant to corrosion and is used in nuclear reactors.

name: Niobium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like columbite and pyrochlore
hazards: Generally low toxicity; compounds can be harmful if inhaled or ingested
spectralLines: Lines in the ultraviolet region of the spectrum
funFacts: Niobium is used in superconducting magnets and as an alloying agent in steel.

name: Molybdenum
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like molybdenite and wulfenite
hazards: Excessive exposure can cause skin irritation
spectralLines: Lines in UV spectrum
funFacts: Molybdenum increases the strength and corrosion resistance of steel.

name: Technetium
naturalOccurrence: Artificially produced; only trace amounts found in uranium ores
hazards: Radioactive isotopes require careful handling
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Technetium was the first artificially produced element.

name: Ruthenium
naturalOccurrence: Found in platinum ores and in small quantities in Earth's crust
hazards: Some compounds are toxic and reactive
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Ruthenium is used to harden platinum and palladium alloys.

name: Rhodium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in platinum ores
hazards: Generally low toxicity but compounds may be hazardous
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Rhodium is the rarest and most valuable precious metal.

name: Palladium
naturalOccurrence: Found in platinum ores and meteorites
hazards: Generally low toxicity but exposure should be minimized
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Palladium can absorb up to 900 times its own volume of hydrogen.

name: Silver
naturalOccurrence: Found in ores like argentite and in native form
hazards: Low toxicity but can cause skin irritation
spectralLines: Lines in the visible region
funFacts: Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of all metals.

name: Cadmium
naturalOccurrence: Found in zinc ores and in trace amounts in Earth's crust
hazards: Toxic and carcinogenic; exposure should be avoided
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Cadmium is a byproduct of zinc refining and is used in rechargeable batteries.

name: Indium
naturalOccurrence: Found in zinc ores like sphalerite
hazards: Low toxicity but should be handled with care in dust or vapor form
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Indium is used in touchscreens and solar panels for its conductive properties.

name: Tin
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like cassiterite
hazards: Generally low toxicity; some organotin compounds are toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Tin has been used for thousands of years in alloys like bronze.

name: Antimony
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like stibnite
hazards: Exposure can cause skin and lung irritation
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Antimony has been used since ancient times in cosmetics and alloys.

name: Tellurium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in telluride minerals and as a byproduct of copper refining
hazards: Tellurium compounds may cause garlic-like odor and respiratory issues
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Tellurium is one of the rarest elements on Earth.

name: Iodine
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in seawater and certain minerals
hazards: Iodine vapors can be irritating; excessive ingestion can be harmful
spectralLines: Lines in the violet region
funFacts: Iodine is essential for thyroid health.

name: Xenon
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in trace amounts in the Earth's atmosphere
hazards: Generally non-toxic but can displace oxygen
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Xenon is used in flash lamps and ion propulsion systems.

name: Cesium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in trace amounts in minerals like pollucite
hazards: Highly reactive; can ignite in air and explode in water
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Cesium is one of the most reactive elements and is used in atomic clocks.

name: Barium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like barite and witherite
hazards: Toxic if ingested; some compounds are harmful
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Barium compounds are used in fireworks to produce green colors.

name: Lanthanum
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in rare-earth minerals like monazite and bastnsite
hazards: Generally low toxicity but should be handled with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Lanthanum is used in camera lenses to reduce chromatic aberration.

name: Cerium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like monazite and bastnsite
hazards: Exposure to dust can irritate eyes and lungs
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Cerium is the most abundant of the rare earth elements.

name: Praseodymium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in rare-earth minerals like monazite
hazards: Inhalation of dust may cause irritation
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Praseodymium is used to create strong magnets.

name: Neodymium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like monazite and bastnsite
hazards: Dust can cause irritation; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Neodymium magnets are among the strongest permanent magnets.

name: Promethium
naturalOccurrence: Not found naturally; produced in nuclear reactors
hazards: Radioactive; handle with protective equipment
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Promethium is one of the rarest elements and is radioactive.

name: Samarium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like monazite and bastnsite
hazards: Dust can irritate lungs and eyes
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Samarium is used in magnets that retain strength at high temperatures.

name: Europium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like monazite and bastnsite
hazards: Should be handled with care; dust may cause irritation
spectralLines: Lines in visible region used in phosphors
funFacts: Europium is essential for red phosphors in TV and LED screens.

name: Gadolinium
naturalOccurrence: Found in rare-earth minerals like monazite
hazards: Should be handled with care; dust inhalation may be harmful
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Gadolinium is used in medical imaging and electronics.

name: Terbium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like monazite and xenotime
hazards: Dust inhalation may be harmful; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Terbium is used in fluorescent lamps and solid-state devices.

name: Dysprosium
naturalOccurrence: Found in rare-earth minerals like xenotime and monazite
hazards: Dust can be irritating; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Dysprosium is used in high-performance magnets and nuclear applications.

name: Holmium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like monazite and gadolinite
hazards: Handle with care; dust may irritate skin or lungs
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Holmium has the highest magnetic moment of any naturally occurring element.

name: Erbium
naturalOccurrence: Occurs in minerals like monazite and xenotime
hazards: Dust may irritate skin and lungs; handle carefully
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Erbium-doped glass is used in fiber-optic communication.

name: Thulium
naturalOccurrence: Rare; occurs in monazite and gadolinite
hazards: Handle with care; dust may irritate lungs or eyes
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Thulium is the rarest of the naturally occurring lanthanides.

name: Ytterbium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like monazite and xenotime
hazards: Dust may cause irritation; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Ytterbium is used in atomic clocks and some lasers.

name: Lutetium
naturalOccurrence: Found in rare-earth minerals like monazite
hazards: Low toxicity but should be handled carefully
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Lutetium is the heaviest and last of the lanthanides.

name: Hafnium
naturalOccurrence: Found in zirconium ores
hazards: Low toxicity but handle dust with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Hafnium has excellent corrosion resistance and high melting point.

name: Tantalum
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like tantalite and columbite
hazards: Low toxicity; fine powders may be flammable
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Tantalum is highly corrosion-resistant and used in electronics.

name: Tungsten
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like wolframite and scheelite
hazards: Low toxicity; fine powders can ignite
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals.

name: Rhenium
naturalOccurrence: Extremely rare; found in molybdenite and copper ores
hazards: Low toxicity; handle fine powders carefully
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Rhenium has one of the highest melting points and densities of any element.

name: Osmium
naturalOccurrence: Found in platinum ores and alluvial deposits
hazards: Osmium tetroxide is highly toxic and volatile
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.

name: Iridium
naturalOccurrence: Found in platinum ores and meteorites
hazards: Relatively non-toxic; fine powders may be irritating
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Iridium is highly corrosion-resistant and among the densest metals.

name: Platinum
naturalOccurrence: Found in platinum ores and alluvial deposits
hazards: Low toxicity; some salts can cause allergic reactions
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Platinum is widely used as a catalyst in chemical reactions.

name: Gold
naturalOccurrence: Found in native deposits, ores, and alluvial deposits
hazards: Generally non-toxic
spectralLines: Lines in visible region; characteristic yellow color
funFacts: Gold is a highly malleable and ductile metal used for coins and jewelry.

name: Mercury
naturalOccurrence: Found in cinnabar ore
hazards: Highly toxic; can cause mercury poisoning
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Mercury is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature.

name: Thallium
naturalOccurrence: Found in trace amounts in minerals like crookesite
hazards: Highly toxic; ingestion or inhalation can be fatal
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Thallium was historically used in rat poisons and insecticides.

name: Lead
naturalOccurrence: Found in ores such as galena
hazards: Highly toxic; prolonged exposure can cause lead poisoning
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Lead has been used since ancient times for pipes, paints, and cosmetics.

name: Bismuth
naturalOccurrence: Found in bismuthinite and other minerals
hazards: Low toxicity; generally considered safe
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Bismuth crystals often form colorful, stair-step structures.

name: Polonium
naturalOccurrence: Rare; found in uranium ores
hazards: Extremely radioactive and highly toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Polonium was discovered by Marie Curie and is highly radioactive.

name: Astatine
naturalOccurrence: Extremely rare; occurs as a decay product of uranium and thorium
hazards: Highly radioactive; must be handled with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring halogen.

name: Radon
naturalOccurrence: Produced from decay of radium in uranium ores
hazards: Radioactive; inhalation is highly dangerous
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Radon is a radioactive noble gas and is colorless and odorless.

name: Francium
naturalOccurrence: Extremely rare; produced from decay of actinium
hazards: Highly radioactive; extremely rare
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Francium is the rarest naturally occurring alkali metal.

name: Radium
naturalOccurrence: Found in uranium and thorium ores
hazards: Highly radioactive; carcinogenic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Radium glows faintly blue in the dark due to radioactivity.

name: Actinium
naturalOccurrence: Found in uranium and thorium ores
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Actinium was discovered in 1899 and is the first of the actinides.

name: Thorium
naturalOccurrence: Found in thorite and monazite
hazards: Radioactive; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Thorium is a potential alternative nuclear fuel to uranium.

name: Protactinium
naturalOccurrence: Found in uranium ores in trace amounts
hazards: Radioactive; highly toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Protactinium is rare and highly radioactive, making it difficult to study.

name: Uranium
naturalOccurrence: Found in minerals like uraninite
hazards: Radioactive; toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Uranium was used as the first nuclear fuel in reactors and weapons.

name: Neptunium
naturalOccurrence: Trace amounts in uranium ores; mostly synthetic
hazards: Radioactive; highly toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Neptunium was the first transuranic element discovered.

name: Plutonium
naturalOccurrence: Trace amounts from decay of uranium and neptunium; mostly synthetic
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Plutonium is used in nuclear weapons and reactors.

name: Americium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with care
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Americium is commonly used in household smoke detectors.

name: Curium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Curium was named after Marie and Pierre Curie.

name: Berkelium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Berkelium was named after the city of Berkeley, California.

name: Californium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Californium is used as a neutron source for starting nuclear reactors.

name: Einsteinium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Einsteinium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion.

name: Fermium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Fermium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb explosion.

name: Mendelevium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Mendelevium is named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table.

name: Nobelium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Nobelium is named in honor of Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite.

name: Lawrencium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; extremely toxic
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Lawrencium is named after Ernest O. Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

name: Rutherfordium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Rutherfordium was named after physicist Ernest Rutherford.

name: Dubnium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Dubnium was named after Dubna, Russia, where it was first synthesized.

name: Seaborgium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Seaborgium was named after Glenn T. Seaborg, co-discoverer of many transuranium elements.

name: Bohrium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Bohrium was named after Danish physicist Niels Bohr.

name: Hassium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Hassium was named after the German state of Hesse.

name: Meitnerium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Meitnerium was named after physicist Lise Meitner.

name: Darmstadtium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Darmstadtium was named after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was first synthesized.

name: Roentgenium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Roentgenium was named after Wilhelm Rntgen, discoverer of X-rays.

name: Copernicium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Copernicium was named after astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.

name: Nihonium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Nihonium was named after Japan ('Nihon' in Japanese).

name: Flerovium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Flerovium was named after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions in Dubna, Russia.

name: Moscovium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Moscovium was named after Moscow, Russia, near the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research.

name: Livermorium
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Livermorium was named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

name: Tennessine
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Tennessine was named after the US state of Tennessee, home of Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

name: Oganesson
naturalOccurrence: Synthetic; does not occur naturally
hazards: Radioactive; handle with extreme care
spectralLines: Predicted lines in UV and visible regions
funFacts: Oganesson was named in honor of Russian physicist Yuri Oganessian.
